targets.query: SELECT last("total_number_of_nodes") - min("number_of_nodes") FROM "elasticsearch_cluster_health" WHERE $timeFilter AND "project_name" =~ /^$project$/ GROUP BY time($__interval) fill(null)
SELECT max("current_open") as "open" FROM "elasticsearch_http" WHERE $timeFilter AND node_name =~ /$node_name/ AND "project_name" =~ /^$project$/ GROUP BY time($interval), "node_name" fill(null)

panels.description: The Rx(receiving) and Tx(transmitting) package size

targets.query: SELECT non_negative_derivative("rx_size_in_bytes", 1s) FROM "elasticsearch_transport" WHERE "node_name" =~ /^$node_name$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), "node_name", fill(none)
SELECT non_negative_derivative("rx_size_in_bytes", 1s) FROM "elasticsearch_transport" WHERE "node_name" =~ /^$node_name$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), "node_name", fill(none)

panels.title: Transport size

panels.description: Elasticsearch is set up to initiate garbage collections whenever JVM heap usage hits 75 percent. As shown above, it may be useful to monitor which nodes exhibit high heap usage, and set up an alert to find out if any node is consistently using over 85 percent of heap memory; this indicates that the rate of garbage collection isn’t keeping up with the rate of garbage creation. To address this problem, you can either increase your heap size (as long as it remains below the recommended guidelines stated above), or scale out the cluster by adding more nodes.

targets.query: SELECT mean("mem_heap_used_percent")  FROM "elasticsearch_jvm" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), node_name, *

panels.title: JVM heap usage percent

panels.description: Because garbage collection uses resources (in order to free up resources!), you should keep an eye on its frequency and duration to see if you need to adjust the heap size. Setting the heap too large can result in long garbage collection times; these excessive pauses are dangerous because they can lead your cluster to mistakenly register your node as having dropped off the grid ( Because the master node checks the status of every other node every 30 seconds, if any node’s garbage collection time exceed 30 seconds, it will lead the master to believe that the node has failed).
panels.title: GC time

targets.query: SELECT 100*(mean("total_total_in_bytes") - mean("total_free_in_bytes"))/ mean("total_total_in_bytes") FROM "elasticsearch_fs" WHERE "node_name" =~ /^$node_name$/ AND "project_name" =~ /^$project$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY "node_name" ,"node_host", time($interval)
SELECT mean("total_total_in_bytes") FROM "elasticsearch_fs" WHERE "node_name" =~ /^$node_name$/ AND "project_name" =~ /^$project$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), "node_name", "node_host"

SELECT mean("total_total_in_bytes") -mean( "total_available_in_bytes") FROM "elasticsearch_fs" WHERE "node_name" =~ /^$node_name$/ AND "project_name" =~ /^$project$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY  time($interval), "node_name", "node_host"
SELECT mean("value") FROM "cpu/usage_rate" WHERE "pod_name" =~ /^$node_name$/ AND "type" = 'pod' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), "pod_name"
SELECT mean("value") FROM "cpu/usage_rate" WHERE "pod_name" =~ /^$node_name$/ AND "type" = 'pod' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), "pod_name"

SELECT  mean(flush_total) as "flush", mean(get_exists_total) as "get-exists", mean(get_missing_total) as "get-missing", mean(get_total) as "get", mean(indexing_delete_total) as "indexing-delete", mean(indexing_index_total) as "indexing-index", mean(indexing_noop_update_total) as "indexing-noop-update", mean(merges_total) as "merges", mean(percolate_total) as "percolate", mean(refresh_total) as "refresh", mean(search_fetch_total) as "search-fetch", mean(search_query_total) as "search-query", mean(search_scroll_total) as "search-scroll", mean(suggest_total) as "suggest", mean(warmer_total) as "warmer"  FROM "elasticsearch_indices" WHERE node_name =~ /$node_name/ AND "project_name" =~ /^$project$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *

SELECT mean(merges_total_time_in_millis) AS "merges-total",mean(flush_total_time_in_millis) AS "flush-total",mean(get_exists_time_in_millis) AS "get-exists",mean(get_missing_time_in_millis) AS "get-missing",mean(get_time_in_millis) AS "get",mean(indexing_delete_time_in_millis) AS "indexing-delete",mean(indexing_index_time_in_millis) AS "indexing-index",mean(indexing_throttle_time_in_millis) AS "indexing-throttle",mean(merges_total_stopped_time_in_millis) AS "merges-total-stopped",mean(merges_total_throttled_time_in_millis) AS "merges-total-throttled",mean(merges_total_time_in_millis) AS "merges-total",mean(percolate_time_in_millis) AS "percolate",mean(recovery_throttle_time_in_millis) AS "recovery-throttle",mean(refresh_total_time_in_millis) AS "refresh-total",mean(search_fetch_time_in_millis) AS "search-fetch",mean(search_query_time_in_millis) AS "search-query",mean(search_scroll_time_in_millis) AS "search-scroll",mean(store_throttle_time_in_millis) AS "store-throttle",mean(suggest_time_in_millis) AS "suggest",mean(warmer_total_time_in_millis) AS "warmer-total" FROM "elasticsearch_indices" WHERE node_name =~ /$node_name/ AND "project_name" =~ /^$project$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *

panels.description:
If you notice the indexing latency increasing, you may be trying to index too many documents at one time (Elasticsearch’s documentation recommends starting with a bulk indexing size of 5 to 15 megabytes and increasing slowly from there).
If you are planning to index a lot of documents and you don’t need the new information to be immediately available for search, you can optimize for indexing performance over search performance by decreasing refresh frequency until you are done indexing.
Flush latency:  If you see this metric increasing steadily, it could indicate a problem with slow disks

targets.query: SELECT mean("indexing_index_time_in_millis")/ mean("indexing_index_total") FROM "elasticsearch_indices" WHERE "node_name" =~ /^$node_name$/ AND "project_name" =~ /^$project$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY "node_name", time($interval)

SELECT mean("flush_total_time_in_millis")/mean("flush_total") FROM "elasticsearch_indices" WHERE "node_name" =~ /^$node_name$/ AND "project_name" =~ /^$project$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY "node_name", time($interval)

SELECT mean("get_exists_time_in_millis")/mean("get_exists_total") FROM "elasticsearch_indices" WHERE "node_name" =~ /^$node_name$/ AND "project_name" =~ /^$project$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY "node_name", time($interval)

SELECT mean("search_query_time_in_millis")/mean("search_query_total") FROM "elasticsearch_indices" WHERE "node_name" =~ /^$node_name$/ AND "project_name" =~ /^$project$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY "node_name", time($interval)

SELECT mean("search_fetch_time_in_millis")/mean("search_fetch_total") FROM "elasticsearch_indices" WHERE "node_name" =~ /^$node_name$/ AND "project_name" =~ /^$project$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY "node_name", time($interval)

panels.title: Requests latency

panels.description: The size of each thread pool’s queue represents how many requests are waiting to be served while the node is currently at capacity. The queue allows the node to track and eventually serve these requests instead of discarding them. Thread pool rejections arise once the thread pool’s maximum queue size (which varies based on the type of thread pool) is reached.
panels.title: Rejected requests

panels.description: The size of each thread pool’s queue represents how many requests are waiting to be served while the node is currently at capacity.
panels.title: Thread pool queues

rows.title: Thread pool queues and requests metrics
